key_points: There has been a sharp rise in cyberattacks targeting critical infrastructure and physical business operations.
Ransomware attacks have increased by 102% in the first half of 2021 compared to the start of last year, according to Check Point Software.
The US Department of Justice created a ransomware task force in April, following a surge in extortion-related cyberattacks.
Experts warn that without cooperation and investment from the private sector, ransomware attacks are likely to persist.
Cybercriminal groups like REvil and DarkSide, based in Russia, have been responsible for some of these attacks, operating 'ransomware-as-a-service' businesses.
The US government and private sector are being urged to improve cybersecurity practices to protect against ransomware attacks.
The pandemic has exacerbated the situation, with the shift to remote work revealing significant vulnerabilities in cyber defenses.
Critical infrastructure is increasingly connected to the internet, making it more susceptible to cyberattacks.
Healthcare facilities and other vital services have been targeted by hackers during the pandemic, highlighting the urgent need for enhanced cybersecurity.
President Joe Biden signed an executive order to improve cybersecurity practices among companies working for the government.
spokespersons: Katell Thielemann (Vice President Analyst, Gartner for security and risk management)
Mark Ostrowski (Head of Engineering, Check Point)
Eric Cole (Former cybersecurity commissioner to the Obama administration, Author)
